entry.string:
# this box you can run by option clicking on it, here's the code
def start(): print "Starting..."
def keepGoing(): # _t is a magic variable that goes from 0 to 1 (and beyond) to get you the position of the mouse or the time slider over this element. 0 means at the left of this box, 1 means at the very right, 0.5 means in the middle print "...ongoing at time %f... " % _t
def stop(): print "... Stopping"
# start is called once, keepGoing is called while the box continues to run and finally stop is called just before the box isn't run any more _r = start, keepGoing, stop
# final note: you can make one of these boxes using the templating system (assuming you have the templates installed) # on the sheet hit 't' and select (or start typing) "tutorial.runningbox"

label= """this is a box with code in it, click to select it""" width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

# this is another box you can run by option clicking on it, here's the code
def keepGoing(): print "...second box is ongoing at time %f... " % _t
_r = keepGoing

label= """if this begins to look like a time-line then that's because it is. Only it's a timeline with code in it.""" width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

# you can just have any old code in here as well
print "any old print thing"

# _r can be set to other things. Of particular interest: a python generator � very, very useful for animation
def aGenerator(): print "hello" yield 1 print "there" yield 1 print "everyone" yield 1 for n in range(0, 10): print "counting up %i " % n yield 1 for n in floatRange(0, 10, 20): print "counting down %f " % n yield 1 print "all done"
# watch that () _r = aGenerator()

label= """Just to the left of this text there's a red line that can be used to execute boxes by dragging it.

You might be able to grab the line from here, or you can pan over a bit using the middle mouse button (or a drag gesture on a laptop).""" width=300 opacity=0.5 #--------------------------------------------- from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear() text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2()) text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label) text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity) _self.lines.add(text) _self.noFrame=1
